Sir Archibald Geikie. 
two-stone lithography: the one stone identical throughout, the 
other stone different for each page. 
This has, so far as I know, been referred to on 
every occasion when Antarctic publications have been under 
discussion, so that I cannot tell how the Royal Society office 
can have been led to adopt the belief that the material for 
publication was exhausted with the present volume, except that 
the wish may have been father to the thought. 
I have also explained from time to time about the 
other remainder, - the autographic records. About these a 
communication is still due, but my view about it is that the 
Antarctic Committee need make no provision for its publication. 
It may be considered as a scientific paper of an ordinary 
character, and therefore qualified for publication either by 
The Royal Society of by some other learned body. 
I have no doubt that the Meteorological Committee 
would include it in their publications if the learned societies 
preferred not to be troubled with it. No estimate is here-
fore needed with regard to this. 
The only point about which there has been any doubt 
throughout the whole of the negotiations has been the form to 
be adopted for the publication of the circum-polar observations. 
I had some talk with von Drygalski, and after the 
experience of the present volume, I do not think that any 
amount of text can really take the place of maps. 
If the Geographical Society would prefer the 'balance' 
instead of the publication of the results of the expedition 
which they were at such pains to initiate, I should be delighted 
to transfer to them the material that we possess, to be dealt 
with by them in any ay that they see fit. 
Believe me, 
Yours very truly, 
W.N. Shaw
